questions.text: Left posterior sector of liver consists of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Caudate lobe: I Left lobe: II, III, IV Right lobe: V, VI, VII, VIII In the right lobe we have anteromedial and posterolateral sector. - Anteromedial sector: Segment V anteriorly and segment VIII posteriorly - Posterolateral sector: Segment VI anteriorly and segment VII posteriorly In the left lobe we have a anterior sector and a posterior sector. - Anterior sector is divided by the umbilical fissure into segment IV and segment III . Posterior sector is comprised of only one segment, segment II So the answer to the above question is option C as left posterior sector consists of segment II.

choices.text: Blood supply from both right and left hepatic artery
Ductal drainage from both right and left duct
Venous drainage is mainly by left and middle hepatic vein
Supply by both branches of portal vein

questions.text: All of the following are true about caudate lobe except: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Caudate lobe is segment I of liver and lies between the left portal vein and the IVC and extends to the hepatic venous confluence. Caudate lobe is unique - It receives arterial supply from both right and left Hepatic artery. It is supplied by both right and left portal vein. It receives Biliary drainage from both right and left Hepatic duct. Venous drainage is directly into IVC. So undergoes hypertrophy in Budd - Chiari Syndrome. Segment 1 is subdivided into Segment 9 and spigelian lobe.

questions.text: Function of hepatic Kupffer cells is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kupffer cells are derived from the macrophage-monocyte system, they are irregular stellate-shaped cells that line the sinusoids. Their main role is phagocytosis. they play a major role in the trapping of foreign substances and initiating an infammatory response. Vitamin A storage and synthesis of extracellular collagen is the function of hepatic stellate cells.

questions.text: Surgeon excises a portion of liver to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament. The segments that have been resected are (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Falciform ligament is the most obvious external landmark on the liver surface. The plane passing through the falciform ligament passes through the left lobe of liver and It divides the left lobe into a medial segment (segment IV) and lateral segment (segment II and III). So if the surgeon resects the segments to the left of falciform ligament he has basically resected segment II and III of liver.

questions.text: What percentage of the blood flow to the liver is supplied by the hepatic artery? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Liver has two sources of blood supply, hepatic artery and portal vein. Most of the inflow of the blood to the liver is via portal vein and it constitutes 75 % to 80% of the total inflow. Hepatic artery forms a smaller but very important source of blood supply to the liver and it constitutes 20-25 % of the total input of blood.

questions.text: Boundary of Morrison's pouch is formed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Boundaries of Morrison’s pouch (Hepatorenal pouch) Anterior : Inferior surface of right lobe of the liver and Gall bladder Posteriorly: Right suprarenal gland, Upper part of right kidney, 2nd part of duodenum, Hepatic fexure of colon, Transverse mesocolon and Part of head of pancreas Superiorly: Inferior layer of coronary ligament Inferiorly: Opens into general peritoneal cavity

choices.text: IV, V, Vi, VII and VIII
I, V, VI, VII and VIII
I, IV, VI, VII and VII

questions.text: The right lobe of liver consists of which of the following segments: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The liver is divided into two lobes by the main portal fissure known as Cantlie’s line. It extends from the gallbladder fossa to the left side of the IVC. Right and left halves of the liver is delineated by a plane through the MHV and IVC. Caudate lobe: I Left lobe: II, III, IV Right lobe: V, VI, VII, VIII

questions.text: Which of the following is not a capsular plate? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The fascial plates of the liver hilus, represents a fusion of endoabdominal fascia around the portal structures. The fascial plate is formed by cystic, hilar and umbilical plate There is no portal plate. Hepatic veins lack endoabdominal fascial investment and so we do not have a hepatic plate.

questions.text: Right hepatic duct drains all, except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) segment III is drained by left hepatic duct. Option C and D that Is segment V and VI are drained by right hepatic duct. Option A that is segement I is unique in its nature as it is drained by both right and left hepatic duct.

questions.text: Number of lobes in liver as per Couinaud's classification: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As per couinaud’s classification we have 8 lobes in liver. The Couinaud classification of liver anatomy divides the liver into eight functionally independent segments. Each segment has its own vascular inflow, outflow and biliary drainage. In the centre of each segment there is a branch of the portal vein, hepatic artery and bile duct. In the periphery of each segment there is vascular outflow through the hepatic veins.

questions.text: Most common cause of liver abscess in chronic granulomatous disease: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common cause of liver abscess in western countries is E.coli. Most common cause of liver abscess in Asian countries is Klebsiella. Most common cause of liver abscess in children is Staph aureus and this occurs because of an underlying chronic granulomatous disease. Peptostreptococcus is not a common cause of liver abscess.

questions.text: Most common cause of liver abscess: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common cause of liver abscess in western countries and overall is E.coli. Most common cause of liver abscess in Asian countries is Klebsiella. Most common cause of liver abscess in children is Staph aureus and this occurs because of an underlying chronic granulomatous disease. Proteus is not a common cause of liver abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess? (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess is ascending infection from biliary tract due to a distal obstruction. Most common cause of a distal obstruction is stones, but it can also occur because of cholangiocarcinoma. Option A is wrong as trauma can be a cause of a pyogenic liver abscess but it is not the most common cause Colonic diverticulosis and ruptured appendicitis are the other causes of pyogenic liver abscess but they are not the most common cause.

choices.text: Most common route of infection is biliary tree
Most common site is right lobe
Klebsiella is most common in gas forming abscess

questions.text: All are true about pyogenic liver abscess except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is wrong because it says percutaneous drainage of a pyogenic liver abscess is the least curable mode of treatment but infact it is one of the most effective treatment options for pyogenic liver abscess. Option A is correct most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess is ascending infection from biliary tract due to a distal obstruction. Most common cause of a distal obstruction is stones, but it can also occur because of cholangiocarcinoma Option C is correct as Klebsiella is the most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess in Asian countries and if you see gas in the abscess probably it is because of klebsiella. Option B is also correct as pyogenic liver abscess are more common on right as compared to left side.

choices.text: Deep and less than 5 cm size

questions.text: Indication of aspiration in liver abscess:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Left lobe abscess has more chance of rupture hence they are one of the indications of aspiration. Option B is wrong, as If the abscess is superficial and more than 5 cm in size that makes it an indication for aspiration. Multiple liver abscess are difficult to aspirate and manytimes lead to an incomplete resolution so they are not an indication for aspiration. Recurrent liver abscess is not an indication of aspiration. If the liver abscess does not respond to medical treatment for 3-5 days then it is an indication for aspiration.

questions.text: Liver abscess ruptures most commonly in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Liver abscess ruptures most commonly into Pleural cavity. Peritoneal cavity, pericardial cavity and bronchus are other sites of rupture of a liver abscess but it ruptures most commonly into Pleural cavity. If subdiaphragmatic is given in the option than mark subdiaphragmatic. Subdiaphragmatic> Pleural > Peritoneal >Pericardial

questions.text: Anchovy sauce pus is a feature of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anchovy sauce pus is basically a reddish brown coloured pus which is seen typically in Amebic liver abscess. Amoebic liver abscess is caused by entamoeba histolytica and it causes destruction of the liver tissue and the RBC’s and leads to a reddish brown pus formation which is known as Anchovy sauce pus. Lung abscess, Splenic abscess and pancreatic abscess does not lead to such pus formation .

questions.text: Indications for needle aspiration in liver abscess are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B & D) Option A is false as recurrent liver abscess is not an indication of percutaneous aspiration. Option B is correct as left lobe abscess are more likely to rupture hence they are an indication of aspiration. Option C is false as the cutoff for aspiration of liver abscess is 3-5 days and not 48 to 72 hours of failure of medical management. Option D is correct as any abscess > 5 cm in size is unlikely to respond to medical treatment and so it is an indication of aspiration. Option E is false as multiple liver abscess are difficult to aspirate and often lead to incomplete resolution so it is not an indication for percutaneous aspiration.

choices.text: Its usual occurrence is in the right lobe
Extension of abscess from liver to pericardium is the most dreaded.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not correct regarding amoebic liver abscess? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is false as most of the liver abscess patients are managed by medical management and percutaneous aspiration and surgical intervention is required for those who have undergone a rupture . Option A is correct as most of the liver abscess occur in right lobe of liver . Option B is also correct because patient has systemic manifestations and as there is pus in the body patient tends to have fever with chills and other systemic toxic features as well. Option D is also correct because even though a liver abscess can rupture into peritoneal, pleural or pericardial cavity. Rupture in Pericardial cavity is the most dreaded complication as patient can die instantly due to deranged contraction mechanism of the heart.

questions.text: Water lily appearance in a chest radiograph suggests: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is correct as water lily sign is a characteristic feature of Hydatid cyst when it ruptures with its brood capsules floating in the fluid inside the cyst . Option A is wrong as Metastasis in the chest mostly look like a cannon ball metastasis when they spread into lungs via hematogenous route. Option c is wrong as Aspergilloma forms a fungal ball in lungs and looks like a crescent sign or a meniscus sign Option B is also wrong as cavitatory metastasis will appear like a large cavity in the lungs with invasion in the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of pulmonary hydatidosis? (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is wrong as hydatid cyst never shows a drooping lily sign, drooping water lily sign is seen basically in complete duplication of the kidney with non functioning upper pole. Options A, B and C are true as Water lily sign, meniscus sign and rising sun sign are seen in hydatid cyst.

choices.text: Laparoscopic aspiration of cyst is performed
Most commonly located in the right liver
Most common causative organism is Echinococcus granulosus

questions.text: False about hydatid cyst of liver:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) when Hydatid cyst of liver involves deep into parenchyma and it is not responsive to medical treatment and ,aspiration and pericystectomy are not feasible then liver resection is the last resort and is performed in selective cases. Option B is correct as laparoscopic aspiration of cyst is performed and can help in the treatment Option C is also correct as right lobe of liver is the most common site of involvement of hydatid cyst. Option D is correct as most common presentation of hydatid cyst is painless asymptomatic palpable mass in right hypochondrium Option E is also correct as the most common organism responsible for hydatid disease is Echinococcus Granulosus.

questions.text: Not an indication for PAIR treatment in hydatid cyst
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, C, D & E) Option B is the answer as if the cyst is multiloculated and you perform a PAIR in this situation it will lead to partial resolution of the cyst and might even complicate it with rupture. Option C is the answer as if the cyst in Lungs and Brain we do not go for PAIR as the treatment option as chances of spillage are high and if it occurs it will complicate the patient to a great extent. Option D is the answer as if there is recurrence of a cyst after a surgery the normal architecture of the organ and the cyst is distorted and performing PAIR in such cases increases the chance of rupture and leak . Option E is the answer as if we perform PAIR in a patient who has a ruptured hydatid cyst then the contents of the cysts will leak into surrounding tissue and lead to complications like anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Capitonnage is used in treatment of? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Captionnage is a process of filling the gap of the cyst after draining or collapsing the cyst. The hollow which is created after draining or collapsing the cyst is filled with some tissue or omentum or obliterated with sutures, it is performed after we perform pericystectomy for hydatid cyst. Option A is not the answer as treatment of choledochal cyst is excision of the cyst and if required we perform a drainage procedure for the same. Option B is not the answer as dermoid cyst is treated by simple excision of the cyst. Option D is not the answer as most of renal cysts are asymptomatic and left like that without any treatment. Captionage is not done for any renal cyst.

choices.text: Pre-op albendazole followed by surgery is the treatment of choice
Puncture, aspiration, injection, and respiration (PAIR) done in hepatic hydatids.

questions.text: False about hydatid disease: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) lungs are not the most common organ of hydatid cyst. liver is the most common organ affected by hydatid cyst. Option B is correct as we give patients preoperative albendazole and then take the patient for surgery this helps in reducing the risk of anaphylaxis while removing the cyst. Option C is correct as 20% saline is a very effective scolicidal agent, if it made to act for 6 minutes it is 100% scolicidal. Option D is also correct as PAIR is a very effective treatment option for liver and is effective in most of the cases and PAIR is contraindicated for lung and brain cysts.

questions.text: Diagnosis of hydatid disease is by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Serology is the best option among the given options But the IOC is CECT Option A is wrong as biopsy is contraindicated to make the diagnosis of hydatid cyst as it can lead to anaphylaxis . Option B X-rays can help to make the diagnosis of hydatid cyst but the sensitivity of xray is very less so they are not IOC. Option C is wrong as Casoni test is also used for the diagnosis of hydatid cyst but the sensitivity of this test is only 60- 70% so it is not the IOC. So of all the 4 options best test to make diagnosis of hydatid cyst is serology that is serum examination.

questions.text: All are complications of hydatid cyst in the liver except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer as hydatid cyst can never lead to cirrhosis of liver . Option A is correct as sometimes the hydatid cyst can rupture into the biliary system and if does it can lead to obstructive jaundice due to brood capsules obstructing the biliary system . Option B is correct as hydatid cyst can get infected due to any underlying reason and can come with suppuration. Option D is also correct as the hydatid cyst can most definitely rupture due to trauma or other reasons and cause anaphylaxis.

questions.text: During surgical exploration for hydatid cyst of the liver, any of the following agents can be used as scolicidal agent except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) We do not use formalin as a scolicidal agent as it can cause fibrosis and cause damage to the native tissue if it leaks due to any reason. Option A is correct as hypertonic saline is the most preferred scolicidal agent . 0.5% Cetrimide and povidone iodine are also used as a scolicidal agents.

choices.text: E. multilocularis is the most common cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hydatid cyst of liver? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aspiration of hydatid cyst is one of the safe options for the treatment. It is called PAIR (Percutaneous Aspiration Injection of scolicidal agent and reaspiration). It does have complications but is a relatively safe procedure. Option A is false as Surgery may be needed in few cases of ruptured cysts or deep seated hydatid cysts but many cases can be managed by medications and minimally invasive procedures like PAIR. Option B is false as conservative management means you just provide the supportive care and do the monitoring of vitals which is not used for hydatid disease treatment. Option D is also false as E.multilocularis is not the most common cause of hydatid disease, most common cause of hydatid disease is E.Granulosis.

questions.text: All are risk factors for HCC except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Inflammatory bowel disease is not a risk factor for hepatocellular carcoinoma. inflammatory bowel disease mainly ulcerative colitis is a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Option A, B and C is correct as HBV, HCV and alcohol are the causes of Hepatocellular carcinoma.

choices.text: Non alcoholic steatohepatitis is a risk factor
Focal nodular hyperplasia may turn malignant

questions.text: True regarding HCC: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Non alcoholic fatty liver disease is among one of the many causes of Hepatocellular carcinoma. Option B is false as OCP is not a risk factor HCC, OCPs are the risk factors for Focal nodular hyperplasia and hepatic adenoma. Option C is false, as Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign tumor and it never turns malignant. Option D is false as chromosomal anomalies are rarely associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

choices.text: Fibrolamellar variety is not associated with cirrhosis
Alcoholic cirrhosis does not predispose to HCC

questions.text: True about hepatocellular carcinoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & C) Option A is correct as HBV and HCV are both very important risk factors of HCC. Option B is also correct as Cirrhosis is one of the main risk factors for formation of HCC. Option C is correct as Fibrolamellar variant of HCC is distinct from Classical HCC and one of the features is that Fibrolamellar variant is not associated with cirrhosis. Option D is wrong as HCC and RCC are two tumours who have high propensity for vascular invasion. Option E is false as alcoholic cirrhosis is an important cause of HCC.

questions.text: Okuda staging contains all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) AFP is raised in 70 % of patients with HCC it is not a part of OKUDA Classification. OKUDA Classification includes Bilirubin, Albumin, Tumour size and Ascites(can be remembered by a mnemonic BATA).

questions.text: Spontaneous rupture of the liver occurs in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) hepatic adenoma is the benign tumour of liver which is more common in females who use OCPs. Hepatic adenoma has 30-50 % chance of rupture and risk of rupture increases in pregnancy. Most common cause of non-traumatic hemoperitoneum is Ruptured Ectopic Pregnancy. 2nd M/C cause of non-traumatic hemoperitoneum is Hepatic Adenoma. Portal hypertension can lead to hepatomegaly but it does not lead to rupture. Spherocytosis is a blood RBC disorder and it is not associated with liver rupture. Secondary deposits can lead to hepatomegaly but iot does not lead to tumour rupture.

questions.text: Tumor marker for primary hepatocellular carcinoma are all except:(AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alpha-2 macroglobulin is not a tumour marker of HCC. Option D is correct as Neurotensin is a tumour marker for Fibrolamellar carcinoma which is a variant of HCC. Option A is correct as AFP is a tumour marker of HCC and is raised in 70% patients of HCC. Option C is also correct as PIVKA-2 is a tumour marker for fibrolamellar variant of HCC.

questions.text: All of the following are modalities of therapy for hepatocellular carcinoma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) We do not use Nd-YAG laser ablation for the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. Option A is Radiofrequency ablation of tumour is used for unresectable tumours. Option B is transarterial catheter embolization of the HCC, HCC derives the blood supply from hepatic artery predominantly and if we undertake trans arterial catheter embolization of the HCC then it can help In treating the non resectable HCC. Option C is Percutaneous acetic acid injection is another intervention used for treatment of unresectable tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following liver tumour has a propensity to invade the portal or hepatic vein?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Two tumours in our body are most notorious for vascular invasion, they are hepatocellular carcinoma and renal cell carcinoma. Option A is false as cavernous hemangioma is a benign tumour of liver and has no propensity of metastasis or vascular invasion Option C is also false as focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign tumour and has no tendency of vascular invasion. Option D is false as hepatic adenoma is a benign tumour and has no propensity for metastasis or vascular invasion.

questions.text: Ramu, 40-years old male, chronic alcoholic, diagnosed as cirrhosis, presents with a lump in the right lobe of liver. Serum AFP level is normal. Most probable diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) patient is a chronic alcoholic who has developed cirrhosis, and has now presented with a lump. It indicates towards Hepatocellular carcinoma. Only confusing thing is AFP levels are normal, now understand that AFP levels are normal in 30 % of patients with HCC so just the normal value of AFP is not a criteria to rule out HCC as the answer. Option A is wrong as there is no such distinct entity as fibro hyperplasia, we do have fibrolamellar variant of HCC in which AFP levels are normal but Fibrolamellar variant almost always develops in a patient who does not have Cirrhosis. Option C is false as secondaries into liver never present in such a manner. Option D is false, hepatic adenoma develops most commonly in females who are on OCPs and are unlikely to develop in patient who has undergone cirrhosis.

questions.text: Liver malignancies can be studied by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Radionuclide scan is a part of workup for a liver tumour and help in the diagnosis of focal nodular hyperplasia . Ultrasound is the first investigation done in any patient with a suspected liver mass, it helps us tell the extent of the mass and gives an idea about the malignancy characteristics of the tumour and status of the lymph nodes. CT scan is helpful in diagnosis of liver malignancies. Triple phase CT scan is in fact the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma and tissue diagnosis is not needed. Laparoscopy is helpful to look for the peritoneal surface spread of the tumour and look at the gross features of the lesion.

questions.text: Least common presentation of HCC: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common and earliest feature of HCC is Hepatomegaly . Abdominal Pain , Weight loss , Anorexia , Jaundice are other features of HCC. Pyrexia of unknown origin as a feature of HCC is quite unlikely.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Paraneoplastic syndromes of HCC: A) Hypoglycemia - Most common type B) Hypercholesterolemia- Most common Biochemical paraneoplastic syndrome . C) Gynaecomastia D) Hypercalcaemia . CA Pancreas ,CA stomach and CA gall bladder do not produce Hypercalcaemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Renal cell carcinoma can also produce Hypercalcaemia as a paraneoplastic Syndrome.

questions.text: All are tumor markers of HCC except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CA 19-9 is not a tumour marker of HCC. CA 19-9 is raised in cholangio carcinoma and pancreatic cancer. Option A is correct as Neurotensin a tumour marker for Fibrolamellar carcinoma which is a variant of HCC. Option B is correct as AFP is a tumour marker of HCC and is raised in 70% patients of HCC. Option D is also correct as PIVKA-2 is a tumour marker for fibrolamellar variant of HCC.

questions.text: New drug in HCC: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sorafenib is a drug which is used for advanced and metastatic HCC. Sunitinib is DOC for imatinib resistant GIST. It is the first line agent for advanced and metastatic RCC. It is a drug used for refractory metastatic breast cancer.

questions.text: All of the following are true about fibrolamellar carcinoma of the liver except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) AFP levels are absolutely normal in patients of fibrolamellar variant of HCC. In fibrolamellar variant we use neurotensin as a tumour marker. Option A is correct as Fibrolamellar variant Of HCC is same in Males and Females. Option B in correct as fibrolamellar variant of HCC has a better prognosis as compared to classical HCC. Option D is correct as fibrolamellar variant occur in younger individuals.

choices.text: Prognosis is very poor with pulmonary metastasis
Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgical resection.

questions.text: All are true about hepatoblastoma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) hepatoblastoma has good prognosis if treated effectively. Option A is correct as it is associated with FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis) and Beckweith weidman syndrome. Option B is correct as hepatoblastoma is the most common tumour to occur in childhood with most of them occurring in <3 years of age. Option D is correct as the treatment of choice is surgical resection plus chemotherapy with Vincristine, Cisplatin and 5-FU.

choices.text: Common in cirrhosis of liver due to HBV
Surgical resection is treatment of choice

questions.text: All are true about hepatoblastoma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) hepatoblastoma is common in children and low birth weight, beckweith Weidmann syndrome, Familial adenomatous polyposis are the risk factors.Cirrhosis caused by HBV is not a risk factor for the disease. Option A is correct because hepatoblastoma is the most common malignancy of liver in childhood. Option C is true as hepatoblastoma is chemosensitive and responds to Vincristine, Cisplatin and 5-FU. Option D is also correct as the mainstay of treatment is surgical resection of the tumor, chemotherapy is given as an adjuvant agent.

questions.text: AFP is raised in: (AIIMS May 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AFP is raised in 90 % of patients of hepatopblastoma and 70 % patients of HCC. AFP levels are normal in a patient of fibrolamellar variant of HCC.

questions.text: Which of the following liver metastasis appear hypoechoic on ultrasound? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hepatic metastasis which are hyperechoic on USG: 1.Colonic carcinoma 2.Neuroendocrine tumors 3.RCC 4.Choriocarcinoma 5.Multifocal HCC Hepatic metastasis which are hypoechoic on USG: 1.Breast cancer 2.Lung cancer 3.Lymphoma 4.Carcinoma pancreas

questions.text: All are true about hemangioendothelioma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) epitheloid hemangioendothelioma is a malignant tumour of endothelial origin. Infantile variant Of these tumours is benign while the adult variant is malignant and highly aggressive. Option B is correct epitheloid hemangioendothelioma is more common in females as OCP exposure increases chance of occurrence of this tumour. Options C and D are correct as this disease tends to be multifocal and diffuse and so it involves both the lobes and thus it is an indication of liver transplantation .

choices.text: CT scan is used for diagnosis

questions.text: True about biliary cystic adenocarcinoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & C) Option A is correct as CT scan is the best investigation to look at the cystic lesion of the biliary tree. Findings which we see are thick or irregular wall, peripheral enhancement, associated mass, or papillary tumour projections into the cyst cavity. Option B and C are correct as biliary cystic adenocarcinoma is a rare malignant cystic tumor of intrahepatic biliary tree and is more common in females and has elevated CA 19.9 Option D is wrong as these cystic lesions are situated in the intra hepatic region. Option E is wrong as these lesions are more common in females with M:F ratio of 1:2.

questions.text: Indications of liver transplantation are all, except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hepatitis A is an infective condition spread by fecooral route which if treated properly has a very good prognosis and it does not require liver transplantation for the treatment. Option A is correct as Biliary atresia is the most common indication of liver transplantation in children. Option B is correct as sclerosing cholangiitis is also an important indication of liver transplantation in adults. Option D is also correct as cirrhosis is the most common indication of liver transplantation in adults.

choices.text: Given to two recipients after dividing into two parts
Left lateral lobe divided and given to child
Left lateral segment divided from segment 2 and given to child
Part of liver segment transplanted into recipient - depending upon requirement

questions.text: Reduced liver transplants: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) If there is donor-recipient size discrepancy it can be resolved by reducing the size of the donor liver to suite the requirement of the recipient. This process is called reduced liver transplant as we are reducing the size of donor liver before transplanting it into the recipient. Option A is called Split liver transplant. This includes a process in which donor liver is divided into two parts and given to two recipients.

choices.text: Ultrasound guided pigtail catheter drainage of the abscess

questions.text: A 40 year old gentleman presented to surgical emergency with history of high grade fever along with severe pain in right upper abdomen of 2 days duration. On examination the patient is febrile and has a tender hepatomegaly. Ultrasound examination revealed a 4cm X 4 cm solitary abscess in the left lobe of liver along with small right pleural effusion. What should be the MOST appropriate management strategy in the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Any left lobe liver abscess needs to be aspirated or drained along with metronidazole. A small pleural effusion in patients of liver abscess is most likely to be reactive and if not causing any respiratory symptoms does not need a chest tube insertion.

choices.text: It is not commonly associated with prior cirrhosis or hepatitis
Recurrences are seen despite of better prognosis
Increased neurotensin and vitamin B 12 binding factor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fibrolamellar HCC is not TRUE
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fibrolamellar variety of hepatocellular ca although not associated with prior cirrhosis can commonly have lymph node and peritoneal metastases. Neurotensin and vitamin B12 binding factors are tumor markers of fibrolamellar ca.

choices.text: Gallbladder fossa to right border of IVC
From gallbladder fossa to left border of IVC
Gallbladder fossa to midpoint of suprahepatic IVC

questions.text: Cantlie’s line which divides liver into right and left extends from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cantlie line is a vertical plane that divides the liver into left and right lobes creating the principal plane used for hepatectomy. It extends from the inferior vena cava posteriorly to the middle of the gallbladder fossa anteriorly.

choices.text: Potassium and calcium are high in hydatid fluid compared to plasma
Pericyst absent in brain hydatid cyst
Hydatid cyst of liver most commonly involves segment VII and VIII
As per WHO classification CE4 & CE5 cysts are inactive

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hydatid cyst is false
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Potassium and calcium are low in hydatid fluid as compared to plasma while sodium, chloride and bicarbonate levels are same as that in plasma.

choices.text: CVP guided resection of the mass.

questions.text: A 55 year old alcoholic male presents with a 6X6 cm mass in segment VII of liver. Imaging is suggestive of right portal vein invasion. The serum bilirubin is 6 mg/dl, albumin level is 2.6 g/dl, PT of 6 secs with moderate ascites but no signs of hepatic encephalopathy. He has been bed ridden for the past 2 months and can only carry out his daily basic activities. What is the most appropriate management of this patient.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As per Barcelona clinic classification, the patient falls into advanced stage of malignancy (category c); portal vein invasion+, child pugh B, ECOG 1/2. Hence, the best line of management for him would be sorafenib therapy

questions.text: The most common sole agent used in TACE( transarterial chemoembolisation) is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Transarterial chemoembolization or TACE places chemotherapy and synthetic materials called embolic agents into a blood vessel feeding a cancerous tumor to cut off the tumor's blood supply and trap the chemotherapy within the tumor. Most common agent used in TACE:-doxorubin. It is most often used to treat liver cancer but may also be used in patients whose cancer has spread to other areas of the body. Chemoembolization may be used as a standalone treatment or in combination with surgery, ablation, chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

choices.text: Bilirubin statement regarding benign liver lesions

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is not applicable for Okuda staging
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) OKUDA : A) Bilirubin B) Ascites C) Tumor size D) Albumin CLIP: A) Tumor size B) Child Pugh score C) AFP D) Portal vein thrombosis Barcelona clinic score : A) Tumor Size B) Child Pugh score C) Performance status ( Karnofsky /ECOG score for performance status )

choices.text: Focal nodular hyperplasia is associated with intake of oral contraceptive pills.
Type I glycogen storage disorder is a risk factor for Adenoma
Hepatic adenomas in males irrespective of size and number require resection
Hemangioma appears strongly hyperintense on heavily T2-weighted sequences (“lightbulb” pattern)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about benign tumours of liver is not true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hepatic adenoma and not focal nodular hyperplasia is associated with intake of oral contraceptive pills. Hepatic adenomas have strongest association with OCPs . IOC is CECT

questions.text: In a patient of liver cirrhosis with portal hypertension, venous hypertension is most likely to be seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hepatic veins which drain the liver are not a part of portal system. There is no communication between portal system and renal or suprarenal vein. The short gastric veins drain into splenic vein and hence bear the portal pressure.

questions.text: A patient is transported to the emergency department with a knife wound to the right Seventh intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Which of the following structures is likely to have been damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Any perforating wound occurring below the level of the Seventh intercostal space on the right side may damage the liver, which is protected by the rib cage, although it is an abdominal organ lying inferior to the diaphragm.

choices.text: Upper border is at the level of the 5th intercostal space in the right midclavicular line
Liver span is 12 – 15 cm in the right midclavicular line
In emphysema the dullness of the upper border of the liver extends superiorly
Rosenbach’s sign refers to pulsations that are transmitted to the examiner’s hand on gentle palpation of the liver

questions.text: True about examination of the liver are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In certain conditions the dullness over the liver descends rather than ascends. These conditions are: 1. Severe emphysema 2. Large right pneumothorax 3. Gas or air in peritoneal cavity (perforation of a viscus). Rosenbach’s sign refers to pulsations that are transmitted to the examiner’s hand on gentle palpation of the liver. Tricuspid stenosis is likely to be present if the pulsations occur just before ventricular systole, while tricuspid regurgitation is more likely if the pulsations occur during systole.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a long history of heartburn (self-treated with various over-the-counter medications) develops severe epigastric pain and is urgently admitted to the hospital. A gastroscopic examination reveals a small, perforated ulceration in the posterior wall of the stomach body. At surgery, with the patient in the supine position, 150 mL of blood-tinged, frothy grey liquid is aspirated from the peritoneal cavity. Where in the peritoneal cavity would liquid most likely first collect when the patient is supine?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The hepatorenal pouch (or recess or space of Morrison) is situated between the liver and the peritoneum covering the right kidney and suprarenal gland. This recess is the lowest space in the peritoneal cavity in supine patients. Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity will ordinarily collect in this pouch. The right subphrenic space is located between the liver and diaphragm. Although this recess is positioned in the appropriate abdominal quadrant, it is not the deepest space within the peritoneal cavity.

choices.text: Placement of a vascular clamp on the portahepatis

questions.text: During a cholecystectomy on a 64-year-old woman, the right hepatic artery was accidentally injured. In addition to bleeding profusely, the lacerated artery was hidden from view by overlying connective tissue and fat plus pooling blood. Which of the following procedures would most likely be performed by the surgeon to slow, or perhaps arrest, the blood loss?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Pringle manoeuvre is a surgical technique employed when the hepatic artery has been accidentally injured. Intermittent temporary clamping of the portal vein and hepatic artery in the hepatoduodenal ligament (Pringle manoeuvre) can reduce blood loss during parenchymal transection. The Kocher maneuver, in which the ascending colon and descending duodenum are reflected to the left, is often employed to expose and arrest a hemorrhage from the inferior vena cava. The Valsalva maneuver involves stopping the passage of air with the vocal folds to build up intrathoracic pressure, as for coughing or vocalization. Putting a clamp on the porta would not stop the bleeding but could certainly produce major injury to the numerous vascular elements there.

choices.text: Culture of ascitic fluid in spontaneous bacterial peritonitis mostly commonly results in growth of gram-negative bacteria
Odourless and sticky exudative ascitic fluid in children is usually suggestive of primary pneumococcal peritonitis
Ascitic fluid in tubercular peritonitis has total protein < 25 g/L
Treatment of acute episode of periodic peritonitis is colchicine

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tubercular peritonitis is straw colour with high protein content > 25 – 30 g/L, white cell count of > 500 mm3 with > 40% lymphocytes. Periodic peritonitis (Familial Mediterranean fever) occurs in children with recurring symptoms. Colchicine is used for acute episode and prevent recurring attacks. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP; sometimes called primary bacterial peritonitis) is an acute bacterial infection of ascitic fluid. It can occur in children and adults and can in theory occur as a complication of any disease state that produces the clinical syndrome of ascites. The diagnosis is made by paracentesis, and this should be considered in patients with cirrhosis and ascites even when there is a low index of suspicion. The diagnosis is made by an increased neutrophil of 250/mm3 as determined by counting centrifuged ascitic fluid. Ascites culture is negative in as many as 60% of patients with clinical manifestations of SBP and increased ascitic neutrophil count. When culture is positive (40% of cases), the most common pathogens include gram-negative bacteria, usually E. coli, and gram-positive cocci (mainly streptococci and enterococci). Pneumococcal peritonitis may complicate nephrotic syndrome or cirrhosis in children.Should the exudate be odourless and sticky, the diagnosis of pneumococcal peritonitis is practically certain.

questions.text: All are examples of exudative ascites except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High SAAG (“transudate”) cirrhosis, hepatic failure, hepatic venous occlusion, constrictive pericarditis, kwashiorkor, cardiac failure, alcoholic hepatitis, liver metastasis Low SAAG (“exudate”) malignancy, infection (bacterial, fungal, Tb), pancreatitis, nephrotic syndrome, bowel obstruction or infarction, bile leak

choices.text: Cantlie’s line passes from the gall bladder fossa to the IVC
Middle hepatic vein passes through the Cantlie’s line
Caudate lobe has independent venous drainage

questions.text: False about anatomy of liver?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Liver is divided into 8 segments Quadrate lobe is segment IV and lies on the visceral surface of the liver and is subdivided into IVa and IVb. It lies between the gall bladder fossa and the fissure for the ligament teres. It is a part of the right lobe. The caudate lobe (segment I) is supplied by both left and right branches of the hepatic artery. It drains bile into both right and left hepatic ducts. It has independent venous drainage into the IVC.

questions.text: All of the following are used for scoring Child – Turcotte – Pugh classification of hepatocellular function in cirrhosis except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Severity of liver disease is done by Child – Turcotte – Pugh (CTP) scoring or the Model for End Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score. CTP score has a total of 15 points based on albumin, bilirubin, ascites, encephalopathy and INR.

questions.text: All of the following therapies are considered appropriate during the management of an acute variceal haemorrhage EXCEPT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Variceal bleeding is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in those with portal venous hypertension. Prevention of variceal bleeding may be accomplished through administration of nonselective ?-blockers (e.g., propranolol) and routine endoscopic surveillance and variceal band ligation. short-term antibiotic prophylaxis (e.g., ceftriaxone) is recommended or patients with acute variceal bleeding. Management of the bleeding can be accomplished with vasoactive medications, including vasopressin and somatostatin analogues (eg, octreotide). Though vasopressin is the most potent vasoconstrictor, it is limited by its systemic effects. Thus, somatostatin analogues are the preferred agent. Further therapy for bleeding varices should include endoscopy with variceal band ligation.

questions.text: Indication for aspiration of amoebic liver abscess are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Indications of Aspiration in ALA 1. Diagnostic uncertainty 2. Failure to respond to therapy in 3-5 days 3. Pyogenic superinfection 4. High risk of rupture (size >5 cm, left lobe abscess) 5. Pregnancy (Therapeutic trial with high dose Metronidazole is deemed inappropriate)

questions.text: Which of the following liver lesions carry a significant risk of spontaneous rupture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Though hemangiomas are at risk or bleeding if they are biopsied, spontaneous rupture is rare. Adenomas, on the other hand, carry a significant risk for spontaneous rupture with intraperitoneal bleeding. For this reason, along with their potential or malignant degeneration, it is generally recommended that hepatic adenomas be resected once discovered.

choices.text: Segment II III IV V VIII
Segment IV V VI VII VIII

questions.text: Left trisegmentectomy involves removal of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right trisegmentectomy or extended right hepatectomy: Complete resection of segment IV with the right liver (removal of segment IV, V, VI, VII, VIII). Left trisegmentectomy or extended left hepatectomy: Complete resection of segments V and VIII with the left liver (removal of segment II, III, IV, V, VIII).

questions.text: The only FDA-approved systemic chemotherapeutic agent for HCC is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Though systemic chemotherapy has not proven very effective in the treatment of HCC, the multikinase inhibitor sorafenib has been approved or use specifically in these patients.

questions.text: According to the Bismuth-Corlette classification system, perihilar cholangiocarcinomas extending into the right secondary intrahepatic ducts are classified as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Perihilar cholangiocarcinomas, also referred to as Klatskin tumors, are further classified based on anatomic location by the Bismuth-Corlette classification. Type I tumors are confined to the common hepatic duct type II tumors involve the bifurcation without involvement of the secondary intrahepatic ducts. Type IIIa and IIIb tumors extend into the right and left secondary intrahepatic ducts, respectively. Type IV tumors involve both the right and left secondary intrahepatic ducts.

choices.text: Placement of a -tube through the site of injury in the duct.
Primary oversew of the injury intraoperatively.
Resection of the injured portion of the duct with end- to- end anastomosis.
Intraoperative placement of endoscopic biliary stent

questions.text: What is the best initial management for an intraoperatively identified minor lateral injury to the common bile duct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral injury to the common bile duct or the common hepatic duct, recognized at the time of surgery, is best managed with a T-tube placement. If the injury is a small incision in the duct, the tube may be placed through it as if it were a formal choledochotomy. In more extensive lateral injuries, the tube should be placed through a separate choledochotomy and the injury closed over the T-tube end to minimize the risk of subsequent stricture formation.

choices.text: Serologic testing for Entamoeba histolytica and oral metronidazole

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visiting from Mexico comes to the emergency department with a history of 2 weeks of right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, fevers, chills, and diarrhea. He is febrile to 102.9°F. His heart rate and blood pressure are 120 beats/min and 100/75 mmHg, respectively. Laboratory results include a white blood cell count of 16,000/mm3, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 50 IU/L, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 93 IU/L. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a 4 × 7-cm round, hypoechoic, nonhomogeneous lesion abutting the liver capsule without rim echoes. Subsequent CT also demonstrates a non–rim-enhancing hypoechoic lesion with a smaller adjacent lesion measuring 2 × 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Amebic abscesses are caused by the protozoan E. histolytica, which is spread through the fecal–oral route. Once ingested, the cysts pass into the intestines, where the trophozoite is released and transmitted to the colon. These trophozoites can then invade the colonic mucosa and subsequently reach the liver via the portal vein. In the liver, these trophozoites produce a liquefaction necrosis responsible for the classic “anchovy paste” appearance. Protozoa are not usually isolated from the abscess because they arelocated in the peripheral rim of tissue Diagnosis requires hepatic imaging (usually ultrasound or CT) and serologic testing for the presence of E. histolytica antibodies as well as a thorough history and physical examination. The patient in this question is a young man from an endemic region who has signs and symptoms similar to those of a pyogenic liver abscess; however, his classic history and the lack of rim enhancement on imaging suggest the diagnosis of amebic abscess rather than a pyogenic abscess. Hepatic amebiasis is treated primarily by the administration of amebicidal drugs, with metronidazole being the drug of choice. Percutaneous aspiration may be indicated if the patient does not respond to medical management Percutaneous or operative drainage is also indicated in the presence of secondary bacterial infection, which occurs in about 10% of amebic abscesses.

questions.text: A 28-year-old asymptomatic white woman is incidentally found to have a 3.5-cm hypervascular lesion with a central scar in the right lobe of her liver. On delayed images, there is increased uptake of contrast material in the scar in comparison with the surrounding liver parenchyma. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Liver enzyme and alpha-fetoprotein levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This patient has focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH), which is often found incidentally on imaging or during laparotomy. FNH is a benign liver tumor that predominantly occurs in women in the third to fifth decades of life. It is similar to hepatic adenoma (HA) but with important differentiating clinical and histologic features and therapeutic implications. Both occur most commonly in women of childbearing age; however, HA is associated with the use of oral contraceptives and anabolic steroids and is also seen in certain glycogen storage diseases. HA is usually symptomatic (80% of cases) and is associated with rupture and bleeding in a substantial proportion of patients, whereas FNH is usually asymptomatic and found incidentally. Furthermore, HA has the potential for malignant transformation, whereas the risk for malignancy in FNH is unlikely but uncertain. Histologically, HA consists of hepatocytes without bile ducts or Kupffer cells. FNH contains Kupffer cells along with a central stellate scar surrounded by fibrous tissue. Scanning for Kupffer cell activity with technetium-99m (99mTc)-labeled sulfur colloid is thus useful in differentiating the lesions. Because of the asymptomatic nature of this patient, small size of the lesion, and negligible risk for malignant transformation, observation is appropriate. Surgical resection is reserved for symptomatic patients or when the diagnosis is uncertain.

choices.text: Discontinuation of oral contraceptives and observation with serial CT

questions.text: Right upper quadrant abdominal pain develops in a 25-year old woman taking oral contraceptives. CT demonstrates a hypodense, 6-cm mass in the right lobe of the liver. A 99mTc-labelled scan reveals a defect in the area of the mass. Angiography reveals a hypervascular tumor with a peripheral blood supply. Which of the following is the appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The imaging characteristics described are typical of HA (hepatic adenoma). Because HA does not contain Kupffer cells, it does not take up radioisotope. This point may be useful for differentiating HA from FNH but not necessarily from other mass lesions of the liver. Percutaneous biopsy of suspected HA is not advisable because of the risk for hemorrhage. HAs associated with oral contraceptives tend to be larger and have a higher risk for bleeding. Regression does not reliably occur with cessation of oral contraceptives. However, for lesions smaller than 4 cm, a trial of cessation of contraceptives or steroids with observation may be attempted. Resection is indicated for most suspected HAs, particularly for symptomatic lesions, for patients not taking oral contraceptives, and if the diagnosis is uncertain. Embolization may be useful for treating hemorrhage in a patient whose HA is inoperable. Radiation has no role in the management of HA.

choices.text: Pain, shortness of breath, early satiety

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with recurrent breast cancer undergoes CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis for metastatic workup. She is found to have a 7-cm liver mass. Follow up triple phase CT shows a hypervascular lesion with peripheral to central enhancement. It is thought to be a hemangioma. She denies abdominal pain or any episodes of jaundice. What would be a reasonable indication for operative intervention?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hepatic hemangiomas are the most common benign hepatic tumor. They have no risk of malignant degeneration and are often found incidentally. They typically appear as hypervascular lesions with initial peripheral enhancement followed by late central enhancement, which follows the direction of blood flow into the lesion. Biopsy is not necessary and furthermore carries the risk of hemorrhage. Asymptomatic uncomplicated hemangiomas are simply observed. Indications for surgical resection include symptoms from mass effect, consumptive coagulopathy manifesting as DIC (seen in Kasabach-Merritt syndrome), high-output cardiac failure from arteriovenous shunting, or rupture and hemorrhage. Enucleation can generally be performed, without formal liver resection being necessary.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with hypertension presents to her primary care physician (PCP) with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. There is a palpable soft mass along her liver edge. Workup is negative for viral hepatitis, and liver ultrasound shows a 4-cm cystic structure that is extrahepatic and separate from the gallbladder. ERCP is performed and demonstrates a biliary diverticulum obstructing the common bile duct. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) When a cyst is an incidental finding with no symptoms and the diagnosis is secure, no further intervention is indicated. In larger cysts, there is a risk of biliary obstruction leading to pancreatitis, cholangiitis, and obstructive jaundice, and symptomatic patients should undergo resection.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with hepatitis C cirrhosis presents for an annual checkup. He denies any new complaints, including jaundice, abdominal pain, ascites, gastrointestinal bleeding or encephalopathy. Temperature is 99.1°F, pulse 85 beats/ min, blood pressure 109/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. What studies should be ordered?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is among the most common cancers worldwide. Anyone with cirrhosis is at risk, and some etiologies of cirrhosis are independent risk factors separate from cirrhosis. For example, in hepatitis B infection, HCC can develop without underlying cirrhosis. Other populations at risk include patients with hepatitis C, alcoholic liver disease, hemochromatosis, alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, primary sclerosing cholangiitis, aflatoxins, HA, anabolic steroid use, and pesticides. HCC screening is therefore recommended in all individuals with cirrhosis. The recommended screening method is ultrasonography every 6 months. Ultrasonography is 60%–90% sensitive, depending on the size of the lesions. Adding AFP testing is no longer recommended due to its cost and false-positive rates

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with Child’s C cirrhosis has an elevated AFP and a new liver mass on ultrasound. Triple phase contrast CT confirms a 3.5 ×4 cm2 mass with arterial enhancement and venous washout. She is otherwise healthy with no cardiopulmonary disease. What is the next most appropriate step in workup and treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In a patient with positive HCC screening, diagnosis is generally made by imaging. Triple-phase magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is more sensitive and specific than triple-phase CT, but the latter is more often used. The characteristic description of HCC is a lesion with arterial enhancement and venous washout. Biopsy is usually not necessary, except for unusual cases in which the clinical diagnosis is still in doubt. Management of HCC is resection, and the most important factor in assessing candidacy for liver resection is a hepatic reserve. In general, a patient with Child’s A cirrhosis can tolerate up to 50% liver resection, and Child’s B up to 25% liver resection. Liver resection is contraindicated in Child’s C cirrhosis, and transplant has better survival than resection in these patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of colorectal cancer 10 years ago, treated with right hemicolectomy and chemotherapy and with no evidence of disease since then, presents with vague abdominal pain. Temperature is 98.7°F, pulse 67 beats/min, blood pressure 132/78 mmHg, and saturation 99% on room air. Labs are remarkable for AST 67 IU/L, ALT 83 IU/L, and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-27 ng/mL. Triple-phase contrast CT shows a new peripheral liver mass that slightly enhances on arterial phase. She has hypertension that is well controlled with medications. What is the most likely diagnosis and most appropriate management of her liver lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Metastatic liver tumors are much more common than primary liver tumors. The liver is the most common site of colorectal cancer metastasis, followed by the lung. Other common sources of liver metastases include pancreas, lung, and breast carcinomas. A new hepatic lesion with a known history of one of these carcinomas is generally sufficient for diagnosis, without a need for biopsy. CEA is usually elevated as well if colorectal cancer is the primary. Characteristics that further support metastasis over primary liver cancer include a history of primary cancer, peripheral residing lesions, multiple lesions, and mass hypovascularity (hence only slightly enhancing compared with adjacent liver parenchyma). Resection of hepatic metastases from colorectal cancer provides a clear survival advantage over any other treatment and should be performed whenever possible.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis has had increasing abdominal distension over the last month. His vital signs are stable, and he is afebrile. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a fluid wave. The initial management of the patient’s ascites should include all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ascites is the most common major complication of hepatic cirrhosis. It is associated with a 2-year survival rate of 50%, and its onset in a cirrhotic patient should prompt an evaluation for liver transplantation. Treatment of ascites depends on its cause, and therefore diagnostic paracentesis is required after a history and physical examination. Abdominal ultrasound can confirm the presence of ascites if it is not certain by examination. The serum-ascites albumin gradient is useful diagnostically. A high gradient (1.1 g/dL) indicates portal hypertension and suggests that the patient will be responsive to medical management consisting of sodium restriction (2000 mg/day) and oral diuretics. Usually, both spironolactone and furosemide are administered to produce fluid loss and natriuresis. Spironolactone alone may cause hyperkalemia, and furosemide alone is less effective. Medical therapy controls ascites in about 90% of patients. When the ascites is refractory, serial therapeutic paracentesis (with or without the administration of albumin or other plasma volume expanders) are indicated. Liver transplantation is the ultimate treatment. A peritoneovenous shunt is an option for patients with refractory ascites who are not transplantation candidates or who cannot undergo repeated paracentesis. These shunts are fraught with potential complications, however, and do not prolong survival in comparison with medical management. TIPS or operative side-to-side–type portosystemic shunts may control the ascites in select patients

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with primary biliary cirrhosis complicated by massive ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, and multiple episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleed requiring endoscopic management presents with hematemesis. Temperature is 98.7°F, pulse 109 beats/min, blood pressure 103/77 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and saturation 97% on 2 L of nasal cannula oxygen. After acute resuscitation with intravenous fluids and blood products, EGD is performed showing multiple bleeding esophageal varices, which undergo endoscopic band ligation. When the patient is stabilized, TIPS is considered. Further workup including chest radiography shows a large right pleural effusion. What is the most important relative contraindication for portovenous shunting?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Portal hypertension is responsible for the majority of the morbidity and mortality associated with cirrhosis, such as variceal bleeding, refractory ascites, and hepatic hydrothorax. Firstline therapy for patients with primary variceal bleeding is endoscopic therapy with variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy. However, there is a high risk for rebleeding not amenable to endoscopic techniques (refractory bleeding) or continuation of bleeding (recurrent bleeding). This patient has failed medical and endoscopic management of variceal bleeding. TIPS is very effective at reducing or normalizing portal pressure. Other indications for TIPS include refractory ascites, hepatic hydrothorax, and Budd-Chiari syndrome refractory to anticoagulation. The mechanism is via diverting blood into systemic circulation and decompressing the portal system. Because hepatic metabolism is bypassed, hyperammonemia may occur manifesting clinically as worsening hepatic encephalopathy. Hepatic encephalopathy is therefore a relative contraindication to TIPS.

questions.text: A 40-y/o man is evaluated for fluctuating jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. Liver enzyme levels demonstrate cholestasis. Ultrasound imaging does not show gallstones or bile duct dilation. What diagnostic test should be obtained next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The findings described are fairly typical of sclerosing cholangitis, which can also be discovered in asymptomatic patients based on a cholestatic liver enzyme pattern. Sclerosing cholangitis is a disease of undetermined cause characterized by inflammatory fibrosis and stenosis of the bile ducts. Primary sclerosing cholangitis may be an isolated finding or may occur in conjunction with a variety of other disease processes, most commonly ulcerative colitis.. Although the cause of primary sclerosing cholangitis is unknown, most attention has focused on an autoimmune or infectious cause. Antimitochondrial antibodies are generally associated with primary biliary cirrhosis but they can be seen in PSC also. The diagnosis is usually made following ERCP showing multiple strictures and dilations, which give a “beaded” appearance to the ducts. Typically, sclerosing cholangitis is a diffuse process that affects both the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

choices.text: Observation, since there is no evidence of choledocholithiasis
Complete surgical excision of the dilated bile duct segment and reconstruction with a hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 22-y/o female presents to the emergency room with RUQ pain and jaundice. Ultrasound shows a normal appearing gallbladder without stones, but a diffusely dilated CBD. Follow-up ERCP confirms a diffusely dilated fusiform extrahepatic bile duct without filling defects, and normal-appearing intrahepatic biliary anatomy. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Choledochal cysts are a rare cause of RUQ pain and jaundice. They are premalignant lesions, carrying a 10%–30% risk of carcinoma, so observation is not appropriate. The most accepted theory of their pathogenesis is related to an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction, which allows pancreatic fluid to reflux up into the biliary tract. This results in chronic inflammation and cystic degeneration of the bile duct. This patient has a type I cyst, which involves fusiform dilatation of the extrahepatic biliary tree and is treated by complete excision and hepaticojejunostomy reconstruction. Type II cysts appear as a diverticulum off the CBD and are treated by excision, as well as biliary-enteric drainage if an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction is present. Type III cysts, also known as choledochoceles, appear as intramural CBD cystic dilatation within the duodenal wall. Their pathogenesis is not clear and so treatment is directed at relieving the biliary or duodenal obstruction (if present). This can be approached via a transduodenal excision or endoscopic sphincteroplasty. Type IV disease involves both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary trees. Treatment depends on the anatomic pattern of disease. Type V disease, also known as Caroli disease, involves only the intrahepatic bile ducts. Surgical treatment ranges from liver resection to transplantation depending on the extent of ductal involvement

choices.text: Normal expected decline after relief of any obstructive Jaundice

questions.text: Two weeks following hepaticojejunostomy for the treatment of a benign bile duct stricture, a patient has a serum bilirubin level of 6 mg/dL. The patient was jaundiced for 4 weeks before the operation and had a preoperative serum bilirubin level of 12 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this current serum bilirubin level?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) After relief of biliary obstruction, there is a prompt increase in bile flow, and normal bile acid secretion resumes within several days. Serum bilirubin levels decline approximately 50% by 36 to 48 h after surgery and 8% per day thereafter. This rate varies depending on the duration of the jaundice. Delta-bilirubin is a form of bilirubin that is covalently bonded to albumin and is measured as part of the direct bilirubin fraction. As such, it is not filtered by the kidneys and has the same serum half-life as albumin, approximately 18 days, which accounts for the slow decline in serum bilirubin levels observed in patients following relief of longstanding jaundice.

choices.text: 270º abutment of the superior mesenteric artery
Tumor located in the neck of the pancreas
Inability to verify malignancy histologically before resection
90º abutment of the superior mesenteric vein

questions.text: A jaundiced, otherwise healthy patient is noted to have a 3-cm mass in the head of the pancreas on CT. EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration shows cancer. The mass abuts the portal vein, but there is no clear evidence of vessel involvement or metastatic disease. You proceed to the operating room. Intraoperatively, you are concerned about the respectability of the tumor. In which of the following situations is resection contraindicated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Criteria for unresectability are:- 1.celiac artery involvement 2.SMA involvement 3.ascites 4.>180` abutment to SMA
